places.name: Berkshire
places.description: Berkshire is a county in south-east England.

persons.name: Jan Baptist vanHelmont
persons.description: Experimental alchemist and physician born in Brussels. Is credited as the founded of pneumatic chemistry and coined the word gas.

persons.name: RobertBoyle
persons.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

persons.name: JohnWoodward
persons.description: Natural philospher with an interest in geology. His collection of fossils and minerals is part of Cambridge University's Sedgwick Museum of Geology. FRSL.

works.name: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London
works.author: John Woodward

persons.name: JethroTull
persons.description: Agriculturist from Berkshire who who developed new agricultual implements such as the horse-drawn seed drill and hoe.

works.name: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London
works.author: John Woodward

persons.name: Henri-LouisDuhamel du Monceau
persons.description: French physician, naval engineer and botanist. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Michel Lullin deChateauvieux
persons.description: Genevan patrician, agronomist, and experimenter on agriculture, known for the design of many agricultural inplements.

persons.name: JohnWoodward
persons.description: Natural philospher with an interest in geology. His collection of fossils and minerals is part of Cambridge University's Sedgwick Museum of Geology. FRSL.

persons.name: Carl WilhelmScheele
persons.description: Swedish-German pharmaceutical chemist. One of the discoverers of what would later be called oxygen (1771) as well as other chemical elements including what Davy renamed chlorine.

persons.name: JosephPriestley
persons.description: Unitarian and political radical forced into exile in Pennsylvania. As a natural philospher and chemist who retained belief in phlogiston, he discovered oxygen and nitrous oxide though not under those names. FRSL.

persons.name: Antoine-LaurentLavoisier
persons.description: French chemist and tax farmer (for which he was guillotined). Developed a new nomenclature for chemistry (much of which is still in use today) and argued strongly against the existence of phlogiston. Davy read some of his writings while in Cornwall which he then opposed and throughout his career maintained an ambivalent attitude towards Lavoisierian chemisty. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: HenryCavendish
persons.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

persons.name: JanIngenhousz
persons.description: Dutch-born British physiologist, biologist and chemist. He was one of the discoverers of the process of photosynthesis. FRSL.

persons.name: JosephPriestley
persons.description: Unitarian and political radical forced into exile in Pennsylvania. As a natural philospher and chemist who retained belief in phlogiston, he discovered oxygen and nitrous oxide though not under those names. FRSL.

persons.name: Antoine-LaurentLavoisier
persons.description: French chemist and tax farmer (for which he was guillotined). Developed a new nomenclature for chemistry (much of which is still in use today) and argued strongly against the existence of phlogiston. Davy read some of his writings while in Cornwall which he then opposed and throughout his career maintained an ambivalent attitude towards Lavoisierian chemisty. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Jean HenriHassenfratz
persons.description: First Professor of Physics at the Ã‰cole polytechnique, Paris, and mine inspector.

persons.name: JeanSenebier
persons.description: Genevan naturalist; pioneer in field of photosynthesis.

persons.name: FrancisBacon
persons.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

persons.name: EdwardLisle
persons.description: Barrister of Moyles Court, Hampshire, who contributed significantly to Observations in Husbandry (1757) which his son published posthumously.

persons.name: SamuelHartlib
persons.description: Born in Elbing (then in Royal (East) Prussia, now in Poland) of a Polish father and English mother, he moved to England in the late 1620s. Hartlib became a major intellectual figure and his 'circle' was one of the major pre-existing groups that helped form the Royal Society of London.

persons.name: JosephBlack
persons.description: From 1766, Professor of Medcine and Chemistry at the University of Edinburgh. Discovered latent heat and fixed air, later renamed carbon dioxide. A correspondent of James Watt and Thomas Beddoes (who studied under him).

persons.name: JohnEvelyn
persons.description: Writer, landowner, gardener, courtier, diarist, minor government official and a  founding Fellow of the Royal Society of London. FRSL.

places.name: Edinburgh
places.description: The capital city of Scotland.

persons.name: SmithsonTennant
persons.description: Tennant was a botanist and chemist and knew Davy through agricultural improvements. Appointed Professor of Chemistry at Cambridge University in 1813, he was killed in a riding accident on France. FRSL.

persons.description: Italian biologist and physician. FRSL.

persons.name: CarlLinnaeus
persons.description: Professor of Physic and Botany at Uppsala University. Developed the modern system of taxonomic classification. ForMemFRSL.

persons.name: PatrickBlair
persons.description: Scottish surgeon, anatomist and botanist. He joined the 1715 Jacobite rebellion for which he was sentenced to death, but following appeals from various Fellows of the Royal Society of London, he was reprieved. FRSL.

persons.description: Professor of Medicine at GÃ¶ttingen University. Race theorist who applied comparative anatomy to classification of human races. ForMemRSL.

persons.description: Swedish chemist and mineralogist. At some point Davy acquired a set of letters from Bergman to Franz Schwediaur written in the 1780s which are retained in the Royal Institution (RI MS HD/27/A). ForMemRSL.

persons.name: JosephBanks
persons.description: A member of the Lincolnshire gentry, Banks sailed as a botanist on James Cook's first voyage to the Pacific (1768-1771). Elected President of the Royal Society of London in 1778 he served for forty-two years until just before his death. The dominant figure in the running of English science during that time, he became one of Davy's patrons and ultimately Davy succeeded him to the Presidency. FRSL.

persons.name: CharlesHatchett
persons.description: He made his money from coach building which he used to pursue his interests in chemistry and mineralogy in the course of which he isolated the chemical element now called niobium. He was a Manager of the Royal Institution, playing a key role especially in running its lecture programme during the 1800s. FRSL.
